head.title: It's U.S. Arrogance, Not Values, That Offends

hedline.hl1: It's U.S. Arrogance, Not Values, That Offends

block.p: Ronald Steel, writing about suspicions that terrorists caused the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 (Op-ed, July 21), misses the point of why certain segments of the rest of the world may harbor resentment at the United States. It is not American ways and values that threaten them, as Professor Steel asserts, but American insistence on imposing these on others.

Ronald Steel, writing about suspicions that terrorists caused the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 (Op-ed, July 21), misses the point of why certain segments of the rest of the world may harbor resentment at the United States. It is not American ways and values that threaten them, as Professor Steel asserts, but American insistence on imposing these on others.

The latest example is the Helms-Burton bill on foreign businesses operating in Cuba, which has embittered European countries, Canada and Mexico. Another example was the intervention in Panama and the arrest of that country's leader.

I have seen how the heart and soul of the Chinese public -- including the once feverishly pro-American college students -- gradually were lost after the United States led the efforts to block China's bid for the 2000 Olympics and after the American fleet was sent into the Taiwan Straits during China's military exercises.
Perhaps a superpower naturally feels the impulse to police the world. But there is obviously a price to pay, and its innocent citizens, unfortunately, are the ones facing the trade-offs.
YAN SUN Asst. Prof. of Pol. Science, CUNY New York, July 22, 1996
